nodes.text: His suggestion is disturbing unworkable and potentially dangerous
As someone who has watched several close friends struggle with heroin addiction I have to ask: what is Watters thinking?
the decision to quit drugs cannot be enforced from the outside.
Locking up addicts against their will would not only violate their rights; it would be likely to prove counter-productive

Drug workers talk about a  circuit-breaker  the event that triggers a person's decision to quit - a long-suffering partner walking out a valued job being lost. The addict realises what they stand to lose if they don't stop using.
This realisation is an internal one
Internal decision is opposite to an external one
Addiction means the person has lost control over their drug use.
Increasing addicts` control over his own life is beneficial
The addiction cannot be  cured  by reducing still further that person's control over their own lives and circumstances as Watters is suggesting.
